p: Another Cinnamomum species also exhibited antibiofilm activity; the essential oil of the trunk bark of C. burmannii was used to inhibit planktonic cell growth and the development of S. aureus and P. aeruginosa biofilms. These results showed that, at a concentration of 0.12% (v/v), the oil was able to inhibit planktonic cell growth of both bacteria by 50%. Fifty percent inhibition of biofilm formation was observed at a concentration of 0.03%, while at a concentration of 0.12% (v/v), biofilms formed by both bacteria were destabilized [ 45].
